message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Handbook on Socially Interactive Agents
Paper Abstract: International audience
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.
purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
**Paper Classification:**
- **Title**: "The Handbook on Socially Interactive Agents"
- **Abstract**: "International audience"

This is clearly a **survey** paper - it's a handbook, which is a reference work that compiles and organizes existing knowledge. A handbook doesn't propose new methods or techniques; it reviews and synthesizes existing work.

Now let me identify all entities explicitly mentioned in the title and abstract:
1. **Socially Interactive Agents** - This is the main topic

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text: Socially Interactive Agents | allowed_domains: ['en.wikipedia.org']
purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Socially Interactive Agents"

Links: [{"title":"Social robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_robot"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Interactive storytelling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interactive_story"},{"title":"Human–robot interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_interaction"},{"title":"Computers are social actors - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computers_are_social_actors"},{"title":"Social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_simulation"},{"title":"Social computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_computing"},{"title":"Human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–computer_interaction"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Socially Interactive Agents:

## Definition and Core Concepts

A social robot is an autonomous robot that interacts and communicates with humans or other autonomous physical agents by following social behaviors and rules attached to its role. More broadly, the concept extends beyond physical robots to include AI-based agents and systems.

## Key Characteristics

Anthropomorphic design features and symbolic cues can influence users' interpretations, potentially increasing engagement, perceived trust, and emotional responsiveness during interaction.(no content)Large language models (LLMs) have begun to be included in discussions of social agents, since they are increasingly embedded within or drive conversational interfaces in robot platforms. Their outputs also elicit social and symbolic interpretations similar to those triggered by humanoids.

## Human Interaction and Perception

Despite initial reluctance to interact with social robots, exposure to a social robot may decrease uncertainty and increase willingness to interact with the robot, and research shows that over time people speak for a longer time and share more information in their disclosures to a social robot.

## Applications

Recent research in human–robot interaction has demonstrated that social robots hold significant potential in mental health contexts. They can be employed in mental health interventions to promote wellbeing and reduce stress and anxiety, and assist in the assessment of wellbeing-related issues.

Additionally, new frontiers of social computing are on the horizon with the catalysis of novel social interaction between humans and AI companions, assistants, chatbots, devices and appliances, and between these nonhuman intelligent agents.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper:** The Handbook on Socially Interactive Agents

**Classification:** **Survey** - This is a handbook that compiles and reviews existing knowledge about socially interactive agents, rather than proposing new methods or techniques.

**Extracted Entities:**

| Entity | Type | Relation | Wikipedia URL |
|--------|------|----------|---|
| Intelligent agent | concept | uses | https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent |

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED

The handbook covers the field of socially interactive agents, which are specialized intelligent agents designed to interact with humans and other agents using social behaviors and communication patterns. The triples_output.json file has been updated with proper classification and complete metadata for all identified entities.

Sources:
- [Intelligent agent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent)
- [Social robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_robot)
- [Human–robot interaction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_interaction)
